Features, Interviews and Long-reads

Year in Review: 15 times Hong Kong made int’l headlines in 2024

Some stories that became international news in 2024 included the jailing of 45 prominent pro-democracy figures, media mogul Jimmy Lai testifying for the first time at his national security trial, and Lionel Messi’s no-show during a much-vaunted match.
by Mercedes Hutton

2024 In Pictures: Pandas, landmark court cases, and a new security law for Hong Kong

From Taiwan’s presidential election to the fast-tracked passage of Hong Kong’s new security law, HKFP has captured some of the most influential moments of the past 12 months.
by Kyle Lam

Hong Kong’s taxi industry at a turning point: Can new regulations bring free-wheeling sector back on track?

Between complaints about drivers refusing to cross the harbour, and vehicles so old some say they are “falling apart,” Hong Kong’s taxis have a bad name among locals and tourists alike. The government is working to change that, but drivers say they’re only cautiously optimistic.
by Hillary Leung

How tiny ‘Village Vehicles,’ which cost HK$1 million to own, keep Hong Kong’s outlying Lamma Island moving

With cars and conventional trucks banned on some of Hong Kong’s sleepy outlying islands, tiny Village Vehicles – or VVs – are essential to keeping their economies chugging. Handmade locally, often with salvaged Toyota parts, it costs HK$1 million to own one.
by Selina Cheng

Heritage under threat: The Hong Kong fish farmers set to lose their way of life to the Northern Metropolis development

As part of the Northern Metropolis project, fish ponds in San Tin will be filled to make way for construction within the next five years. For Lai Kam-dai and her husband Chan, that will also mean the loss of their home of almost 40 years, in which they raised their children.
by Katie Schulder-Battis

Innocent Mutanga on bringing ‘African solutions’ to Hong Kong issues and why empowerment is key to equality

The Zimbabwean, who now has permanent residency and works for an investment bank, arrived in the city with only his clothes, some money and a few books. He has set up an NGO to foster exchanges between different ethnic groups.
by Kelly Ho

Hopeful mothers, unhappy being told to ‘try again’ after repeated miscarriages, spend time, energy, money to have kids

“Having worked on recurrent miscarriage cases for over 30 years, I have an admiration for women. They are very brave,” said reproductive medicine expert Li Tin-chiu.
by Kelly Ho

Hong Kong filmmaker duo on city’s ‘political colours’ and winning at Taiwan’s Golden Horse Awards

Chan Cheuk-sze and Kathy Wong discuss the nuances behind the colours used to represent political ideologies in Hong Kong and Taiwan, a theme explored in their award-winning documentary “Colour Sampling Ideology.mov.”
by Hans Tse
